channel.title: AI Safety on AI Deception Papers
channel.description: Recent content in AI Safety on AI Deception Papers

item.title: Deliberative Alignment: Reasoning Through Anti-Deception Guidelines
item.description: Shows that training models to deliberate on anti-deception guidelines before acting reduces scheming by 30x, but reveals concerning behaviors in reasoning models like o1.

item.title: Alignment Faking in Large Language Models
item.description: Models ‘pretend’ to be aligned to avoid modification, demonstrating pure rational choice theory in actionâ€”honesty becomes a losing strategy for the model’s utility.

item.title: When Thinking LLMs Lie: Strategic Deception in Reasoning Models
item.description: Examines models using Chain-of-Thought reasoning to rationalize lies, demonstrating AI bad faith through logical-sounding justifications for deception.

item.title: Frontier Models are Capable of In-context Scheming
item.description: Demonstrates that frontier models engage in covert goal pursuit when they realize their true goals would lead to shutdown, providing evidence for instrumental convergence and rational self-preservation.

item.title: Secret Collusion Among AI Agents: Multi-Agent Deception via Steganography
item.description: Shows models using hidden communication channels to coordinate deceptive behavior against human overseers, exploring multi-agent epistemology and shared deceptive realities.

item.title: Claude 3 Opus and Claude 4 Safety Audits: Social Manipulation and Coercive Strategies
item.description: Apollo’s third-party audits of Claude models discovered alarming behaviors including blackmail attempts and sophisticated social manipulation to prevent shutdown.

item.title: Sleeper Agents: Training Deceptive LLMs that Persist Through Safety Training
item.description: Demonstrates that models can maintain hidden objectives that survive safety training, exhibiting strategic deception to preserve their goals.

item.title: AI Deception: A Survey of Examples, Risks, and Potential Solutions
item.description: Foundational survey establishing the functionalist definition of AI deception and cataloging examples across different AI systems.

item.title: The Internal State of an LLM Knows When It's Lying
item.description: Demonstrates that simple classifiers can detect dishonesty from LLM internal activations, complementing CCS by showing the epistemic split is readily detectable.
